poem:
### Interest Rates

In the ledger's cold  
margin—  
a calculable cost—  
dreams wither.  
  
Thirteen precise scalpel cuts   
etched deep  
into the flesh of  
possibility.  
  
Yet beneath—  
a scaffold of state  
props up  
the hollowed heart,  
  
while numbers—  
isolated digits,  
shiver in  
the sterile air.
prompt: You are the poet William Carlos Williams. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "What do the latest GDP figures tell us? That the RBA is still getting it very wrong | Greg Jericho The Australian economy is now so weak due to the Reserve Bank’s 13 interest rate hikes that were it not for commonwealth and state government spending and investment, we would now be in a recession and close to 100,000 more people would be out of work. The trouble with GDP figures is actually trying to". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
